A '''401(k)''' plan is a type of employer-sponsored defined-contribution retirement plan. Its name comes from section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/401| title=26 U.S. Code § 401 - Qualified pension, profit-sharing, and stock bonus plans| publisher=Legal Information Institute| accessdate=February 9, 2024}}</ref> It is also generally governed by Title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
A 401(k) allows eligible employees to elect to contribute some of their pay into the plan through [[payroll deductions]]. Contributions are pre-tax, meaning they are not included in the employee's taxable income, and some plans also have a [[#Roth 401(k)|Roth]] contribution option. Sometimes, employers will make [[employer matching contributions]] or other types of contributions into employees' accounts. Employees can invest their money in the investment choices offered by the plan, typically a selection of stock and bond-based mutual funds, and sometimes other less common investments too.
Pre-tax money in the plan grows [[Tax_basics#Tax_deferral|tax-deferred]] and is taxable income when later withdrawn, and Roth growth and withdrawals are tax-free subject to some basic [[#Distributions|distribution]] requirements. There is a 10% penalty for taking withdrawals before age 59½, although there are many [[Early_withdrawal|exceptions]]. Pre-tax money is subject to [[Required Minimum Distribution|Required Minimum Distributions]] (RMDs) starting at age 73 or 75, unless you are still working for the employer. Money in a 401(k) can be left to heirs, and most non-spouse heirs will have to empty the account by the end of the 10th year after your death.
==Advantages== * You get an immediate tax break, because contributions come out of your paycheck before taxes are withheld. Although you will later pay taxes on withdrawals, most people most of the time have a lower tax rate when retired than while working. ** If you think your future tax rate will be similar to or higher than your current tax rate, many plans offer a [[#Roth_401(k)|designated Roth account]], where contributions are taxable, but future growth and withdrawals are tax-free. The choice of pre-tax/traditional or Roth contributors can be a complex [[Traditional versus Roth|tax-planning decision]]. * Many employers will [[Employer matching contributions|match your contributions]] at least partially, for example 50 cents on the dollar for the first 6 percent of your salary you save. If an employer has "frozen" the company's defined benefit plan, the company may increase the company match in the 401(k) plan to compensate for the reduced defined plan benefit. * Tax-deferred growth - meaning you do not pay taxes each year on capital gains, dividends, and other distributions. This feature makes your money grow [[Tax basics|faster]], gives you valuable space to hold [[Tax-efficient fund placement|tax-inefficient investments]], and lets you buy and sell investments for [[rebalancing]] or changing your portfolio without incurring capital gains tax. * Contributions are deducted from your paycheck before you get access to the money. From a behavioral finance perspective, this reduces the risk you will spend money needed for retirement, and helps you build and maintain the habit of saving. * Historically, many 401(k) plans had high fees which made them inferior to [[IRA|IRAs]]. However, 401(k) fees have come down in recent decades, and many plans are competitive with IRAs. Some plans even offer funds with lower fees than IRAs (for example, "Institutional-class" funds) and/or unique investments (for example, a [[stable value fund]] or real estate fund) that may be valuable to certain investors. * When eligible to participate, you can normally contribute more to the 401(k) than to your IRA.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-401k-and-profit-sharing-plan-contribution-limits| title=Retirement topics: 401(k) and profit-sharing plan contribution limits| publisher=IRS| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref> * Contributions made to a 401(k) qualify for the Retirement Savings Contributions Credit ([[Saver's credit|Saver's Credit]]) if you meet the filing and income requirements.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p571| title=Publication 571, Tax-Sheltered Annuity Plans (403(b) Plans)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref> * Especially if the plan is governed by [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Employee_Retirement_Income_Security_Act_of_1974 ERISA], money gets a high degree of [[asset protection]] at the federal level. Money in ERISA plans cannot taken by a creditor, even if they successfully sue you and get a judgment, and if you declare bankruptcy you get to keep money in the plan. * [[Estate planning]] benefits - money can be left to heirs easily via designated beneficiaries (avoiding probate), and non-spouse heirs generally get an additional [[Stretch IRA|10 years]] of tax-deferred or tax-free growth before they have to empty the account.
==Disadvantages== * Plans are generally not designed to allow access to funds before age 59½ without paying taxes and a 10% penalty. * The employer chooses the available funds. They may be better (institutional shares) than funds available in personal accounts, or worse (high-cost funds), and they may or may not fit well within your investing plan. (You may have greater fund selection if the plan has a [[Self directed brokerage account]].) * The plan may only offer funds with embedded fees, and/or charge fees on top of what is charged by the funds. Even seemingly small fees significantly erode long-term performance. * The employer may change the fund selection, fees, or plan rules at any time. * Employer contributions may not become ''vested'' (that is, become the property of the employee) until a certain number of years have passed. * The plans are not insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC).
==Contributions==
A 401(k) plan is only required to offer a pre-tax (also known as a "traditional") account, but many plans also offer [[#Roth_401(k)|Roth 401(k)]] and/or [[#After-tax_401(k)|After-tax 401(k)]] accounts. You can only make these three types of regular contributions through direct payroll deductions.
Pre-tax and Roth sub-accounts share an annual contribution limit, known as the ''elective deferral limit.'' If you are age 50 or older, you get an additional ''catch-up contribution'' limit, which now depends on your age. Catch-up contributions for 2026 must be made to a Roth 401(k) if the employee's 2025 wages exceeded $150,000. These limits are shown in the following table:
{{Retirement Plan Contribution Limits}} Employees can generally contribute up to 100% of their wages as elective deferrals. Contributions are included as wages subject to withholding for Social Security and Medicare taxes. In addition, your employer must report the elective contributions as wages subject to federal unemployment taxes.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc424| title=Topic no. 424, 401(k) plans| publisher=IRS| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref>
In addition, there is an overall plan contribution limit, sometimes called the ''Section 415(c) limit'', which as of 2026 is '''$72,000''', not including catch-up contributions. This limit applies to all contributions into the plan, including:
*employee elective deferrals *employer contributions (matching, profit-sharing, etc.) *employee after-tax contributions *[[#Nonelective_contributions|nonelective contributions]]
===Automatic enrollment and contributions===
Employers may configure their plans to automatically enroll eligible employees, unless that employee opts out. You can normally withdraw automatic enrollment contributions penalty free, if you request the withdrawal within 90 days of the first deferral and completed within 6 months of the plan year in which they began. A safe harbor for nondiscrimination testing is available if plans have: # Initial deferrals of at least 3% of pay, increasing annually by 1% to a number between 6% and 10% of pay, # Either ## An employer match of 100% on the first 1% and 50% on the next 5% of pay, or ## A 3% nonelective contribution, # 100% vesting after two years, # Default investment selections satisfying Department of Labor regulations, and # Annual notice to all employees regarding their right to opt out or change the automatic provisions. Provided the notice requirement is met, and the default investments satisfy Department of Labor regulations, automatic enrollment will be governed by ERISA and preempt any contradictory state laws.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/insights-and-research/perspective/the-power-of-autoenrollment.html| title=The power of autoenrollment| publisher=Vanguard| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref>
===Employer match=== {{Main|Employer matching contributions}}
Employers sometimes offer matching contributions when you contribute to pre-tax or Roth accounts. The matching calculation is typically a percentage of employee contributions up to a certain percentage of your salary (for example, 50% of contributions up to 6% of your salary). Until recently, all employer matching contributions went into the pre-tax account regardless of whether the employee's contributions are pre-tax or Roth. However, as of 2022 the SECURE Act 2.0 now allows employers to offer Roth matches.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-2-omnibus-2022-hr-2954-rmd-75-529-roth-rollover-increase-qcd-student-loan-match/| title=SECURE Act 2.0: Later RMDs, 529-To-Roth Rollovers, And Other Tax Planning Opportunities| publisher=Kitces Nerd's Eye View| author=Jeffrey Levine|date=December 28, 2022|accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref> Any Roth matches are taxable income to the employee and must be immediately vested. Employers do not generally match contributions to an after-tax account, but read your plan rules for details.
Getting an employer match should be a top [[Prioritizing investments|financial priority]], as it is like free money, not to mention money that automatically gets tax-advantaged growth, and asset protection and estate planning benefits.
===Nonelective contributions===
Employers can make certain other contributions not elected by the employees, such as profit sharing contributions. Before 2007, these contributions had to become vested on or faster than either (a) 20% each year from years 3-7 of service or (b) 100% after 5 years of service. Contributions made in and since 2007 must become vested on or faster than either (a) 20% each year from years 2-6 of service or (b) 100% after 3 years of service (with an delayed effective date for collectively bargained plans).
===Multiple plans===
If you have more than one job, the Section 415(c) plan applies to each plan you have access to as long as the employers are ''unrelated'', meaning that the large-share owners are not the same person or close family members. If a set of businesses are owned by closely related people, the IRS considers them part of a ''controlled group'', and the Section 415(c) limit applies to all plans within this group. Controlled group rules can be very complex.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.employeefiduciary.com/blog/is-your-company-part-of-a-controlled-group-you-need-to-know-or-risk-401k-plan-disqualification| title=Is Your Company Part of a Controlled Group? You Need to Know or Risk 401(k) Plan Disqualification| publisher=Employee Fiduciary| author=Eric Droblyen|date=July 30, 2025|accessdate=September 25, 2025}}</ref>
You get only one elective deferral limit per year, regardless of how many plans you may have access to.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.whitecoatinvestor.com/multiple-401k|title=Multiple 401(k) Rules – What to Do with Multiple 401(k) Accounts|author=Dr. Jim Dahle|date=July 21, 2020|accessdate=September 25, 2025}}</ref>
==Investments==
401(k) plans only offer a set of investments selected by the plan provider, usually in the range of one to several dozen options. Choices typically including a selection of stock and bond [[mutual fund|mutual funds]] and maybe other investments. Historically, employer plans have commonly had high fees, both inside the funds and sometimes added on top of the fund expenses. However, 401(k) plans have come down in recent decades, especially at larger employers. Some plans may even offer better investments than can be purchased inside an [[IRA]] or [[Taxable account|brokerage]] account, such as "institutional-class" funds, a [[stable value fund]], private investments, and others.
When choosing funds in a 401(k), pay close attention to each investment's [[Expense ratios|expense ratio]]. The data are overwhelming that low-fee [[Index fund|index funds]] and other passive investments statistically outperform high-fee actively-managed funds in the long run.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.whitecoatinvestor.com/managers-dont-beat-markets/|title=Managers Don’t Beat Markets (Why Index Funds Are the Best Way to Invest in the Stock Market)|author=Dr. Jim Dahle|date=March 18, 2025|accessdate=September 25, 2025}}</ref> Look for funds with expense ratios in the range of 0.10% or less.
Many funds are not necessary to build a good portfolio; in fact, simpler portfolios tend to be better. A great portfolio can be built with just [[Three-fund portfolio|three funds]]. If you have retirement money saved in other places besides the 401(k) ([[IRA|IRAs]], a spouse's [[Employer retirement plans overview|employer plan]], taxable brokerage account, etc.) then you can build a portfolio around a 401(k) with just one good fund. If your plan has no good fund options, see: [[#Expensive_or_mediocre_choices|Expensive or mediocre choices]] below.
Some plans offer a [[Self directed brokerage account|Self-Directed Brokerage Account]] (SDBA) which lets you invest in a wider range of investments. If your plan does not offer any good mutual funds, a SDBA can be used to purchase low-cost [[Exchange-traded fund|exchange-traded funds]] (ETFs). The fee savings of the investments should be weighed against the costs associated with the SDBA.
===Target retirement funds=== {{See also|Approximating Vanguard target date funds}}
The default option for employer provider plans is to place your contributions and employer matches into a [[Target date retirement funds|target date retirement fund]].
Investors have increased their allocation to target retirement funds over time. Vanguard reports data for the employer provided funds it manages in annual ''"How America Saves"'' studies. Among the findings:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/VGApp/iip/site/institutional/clientsolutions/dc/howamericasaves| title=How America Saves 2013| publisher=Vanguard Institutional}}{{dead link}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=June 2025|title=How America Saves 2025|url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/content/dam/inst/iig-transformation/insights/pdf/2025/has/2025_How_America_Saves.pdf|website=Vanguard Institutional}}</ref> * Employee account balance holdings of target retirement funds increased from a 3% allocation in 2006 to a 63% allocation in 2024. * Employee contributions to target retirement funds increased from 4% in 2006 to 85% allocation in 2024. * In 2012, employees 25 years old and younger held 68% of their account balances in target retirement funds. * In 2012, employees with less than 10,000 dollars in their plans held 56% of their account balances in target retirement funds. * Employees using target date target-date funds increased from 69% in 2015 to 84% in 2024.
===Employer stock===
Some plans offer employer stock as an investment option, or contribute the employer match in the form of employer stock. Plans offering employer stock must offer at least three diversified investment options with materially different risk and return characteristics. They must allow you to diversify elective deferral contributions immediately (at least quarterly), and also allow you to diversify employer contributions after three years of service.
Because you already have plenty of risk tied with the performance of your employer, keeping your 401(k) contributions in employer stock is not recommended; in contrast, diversifying out of or even complete avoiding employer stock in your 401(k) is strongly recommended. However, if you hold employer stock with a low basis and you are considering a lump sum distribution rollover of plan assets, see [[Net unrealized appreciation]].
==Nondiscrimination==
Under ERISA, retirement plans including 401(k) plans are not allowed to discriminate in favor of [[Highly compensated employee |highly compensated employees]]. They can make corrections by returning the excess contributions to those highly compensated employees within a specified period of time after the plan year ends. The returned funds are taxable income when received. The time period varies based on other features of the plan, generally from 2.5 to 6 months. If not returned timely by the employer, the employee will also be subject to an additional 10% excise tax.
This rule is waived for plans which meet certain safe harbors. Among other attributes, these safe harbor plans are characterized by certain minimum employer contribution rates as well as more favorable vesting provisions for employees.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Safe Harbor 401k|url= https://www.investopedia.com/safe-harbor-401k-plan-8620915|publisher=Investopedia}}</ref>
==Roth 401(k)== {{See also|Traditional versus Roth}}
An employer may also elect to make Roth 401(k) contributions available; such an account is known as a '''designated Roth account'''. They are the 401(k) equivalent of [[Roth IRA]] contributions, and if the 401(k) is rolled over they can be rolled directly to a Roth IRA or another Roth 401(k). These are normally administered as a sub-account of the employee's 401(k) account. Both Roth and regular contributions are subject to the same contribution limit. Starting in 2024 and later years, RMDs are no longer required from designated Roth 401(k) and 403(b) accounts.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plan-and-ira-required-minimum-distributions-faqs#:~:text=Designated%20Roth%20accounts%20in%20a,required%20from%20designated%20Roth%20accounts | title= Retirement plan and IRA Required Minimum Distributions FAQs | publisher=Internal Revenue Service}}</ref>
===Distributions===
When taking a distribution directly from a designated Roth account (that is, not rolling it over into another account), special rules apply. The account becomes fully qualified when you have met the five-year holding period for the account,<ref group="note">The five-year holding period for a designated Roth account begins on the first day of the taxable year you make your first contribution to that specific account. It does not matter how long you have had a Roth IRA or any other designated Roth account. This is one of several "five-year rules" that apply to Roth accounts.</ref> and are either age 59½ or disabled. If the account is not fully qualified, any distributions are ''pro-rata'' - that is, in equal proportions from the basis (contributions) and earnings within the account. When the account contains IRRs, the rules are very complex,<ref>{{forum link| t=460229| title=<nowiki>[Wiki] Proposed new pages - Rule of 55, Early Withdrawal [and now "Retirement account at a former employer"]</nowiki>}}</ref> and legal ambiguity exists. IRRs generally belong in the "basis" category with respect to the above pro-rata calculation, but the exact ordering between direct contributions and IRRs is determined by the plan rules. To make matters worse, plans are generally not required to populate Box 10 of [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1099r.pdf Form 1099-R] unless the distribution is taken under a [[Substantially equal periodic payments|SEPP]].
In either case, if the designed Roth account is not qualified, you are generally better off to first roll the money out into a Roth IRA and then take withdrawals from the Roth IRA, because Roth IRA distributions always order contributions and conversions/rollovers before earnings. This strategy also avoids the complex and error-prone calculations for distributions from the designated Roth account.
==After-tax 401(k)== {{main|After-tax 401(k)}}
An employer may also allow you to make After-tax 401(k) contributions. These are the 401(k) equivalent of [[Non-deductible traditional IRA |non-deductible traditional IRA]] contributions, and if the 401(k) is rolled over they can be rolled directly to a Roth IRA. These are normally administered as a sub-account of the employee's 401(k) account. IRS rules allow employees to contribute up to 100% of compensation into an after-tax 401(k), up to the overall Section 415(c) limit for the plan. Employers usually limit after-tax contributions to a certain percentage of salary, but the limit is still often much higher than for pre-tax or Roth accounts.
IRC Section 415(c)(1)(A) sets the total contribution limit for both employee and employer contributions to a 401(k), and is summarized in [https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-403b-contribution-limits Retirement Topics 403b Contribution Limits]. Therefore, the after-tax contribution limit is the remaining amount allowed after all employee and employer contributions. And for most people that can afford to contribute, it would allow them to save nearly twice as much money in tax-advantaged space as the combination of elective deferrals and employer contributions.
Just like [[non-deductible traditional IRA]] contributions, earnings are taxed upon withdrawal or conversion at ordinary income rates. Therefore, an after-tax 401(k) account is not great on its own; it's usually better to invest after-tax money in a [[taxable account]], so future growth will be taxed at lower long-term capital gains rates. But, an after-tax 401(k) is useful as an intermediary account, because funds can be rolled over into a [[#Roth_401(k)|Roth sub-account]] or out into a [[Roth IRA]], if the plan allows in-plan Roth rollovers or [[#In-service_distribution|in-service distributions]]. During either rollover, the basis (contributions) rolls over tax-free, and only the growth is taxable. If you are able to roll after-tax 401(k) money into a Roth account quickly, the growth will be minimal, and the overall transaction has the net effect of a Roth contribution. This process is called the [[Mega-backdoor Roth]]. For 401(k) plans with the necessary features, this process allows large Roth contributions in excess of the normal 401(k) limits.
==Plan loans==
Most major companies also offer a loan provision on their 401(k) plans that let you borrow against your account and repay yourself with interest. Restrictions will vary by company but most let you withdraw no more than 50 percent of your vested account value as a loan. You then repay the loan with interest, through deductions taken directly from your paychecks. You must repay the loan within five years unless you use it to buy your main home.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-sponsor/401k-resource-guide-plan-sponsors-general-distribution-rules| title=401k Resource Guide Plan Sponsors General Distribution Rules| publisher=IRS| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref>
Prior to tax year 2018, you had a 60-day window on employment termination, to repay a 401(k) loan balance or rollover the loan balance to an eligible retirement account, in order to avoid the loan balance from being treated as a distribution. The 2017 tax reform (Tax Cuts and Jobs Act) extended the loan repayment and rollover window to the tax filing deadline (including the tax filing extension, if applicable) for tax years 2018 and later. Effectively, this increases the time that you have, to repay or rollover the loan balance.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://sponsor.fidelity.com/bin-public/06_PSW_Website/documents/taxlawchanged-table.pdf| title=Recent Changes in Tax Laws Affect Qualified Retirement Plans and Health & Welfare Benefits| publisher=Fidelity}}{{dead link}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.creditkarma.com/tax/i/401k-tax-reform-loan-repay| title=401(k) Tax Reform Equals More Time to Repay 401(k) Loans| publisher=Credit Karma| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref>
==Early withdrawals== {{Main|Early withdrawal}}
Employer plans may allow early withdrawals under some circumstances, but whether the 10% early withdrawal penalty applies is governed by IRS rules. Plans are only required to allow withdrawals when you separate from service, become disabled, die, for [[Required Minimum Distribution|RMDs]], or if/when the plan terminates.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.employeefiduciary.com/blog/401k-distribution-rules-frequently-asked-questions| title=401(k) Distribution Rules: Frequently Asked Questions for Employers and Employees| publisher=Employee Fiduciary| author=Eric Droblyen| date=May 6, 2025 |accessdate=September 1, 2025}}</ref> For example, many plans do not allow you to withdraw after you turn 59½ if you are still working, even though such withdrawals would be penalty-free.
Early withdrawal penalties apply to withdrawals before you are age 59½ unless one of the exceptions apply. Some common exceptions are listed below. A complete list is available on the [[Early withdrawal|main page]].
*[[Rule of 55]] - if you separate from your employer in or after the year you turn 55 *A series of payments under a [[Substantially equal periodic payments|Substantially Equal Periodic Payments]] (SEPP) plan, useful for [[early retirement]] *Qualified reservist distributions<ref group="note">Qualified reservist distributions may be made to military reservists called up for at least 180 days, with no early withdrawal penalty. Reservists may re-contribute the amount of the qualified reservist distribution to an IRA in the 2 year period beginning the day after the end of their active duty. The extension of the repayment and rollover window is applicable to [[403(b)]] and [[457(b)]] plans, in addition to 401(k) plans.</ref> *Medical expenses *Total and permanent disability *Terminal illness *Death
===Hardship distributions===
Plans ''may'', but are not required to, allow employees to withdraw money from plans for financial hardships, defined as an immediate and heavy financial need, and you are only allowed to withdraw the amount necessary to satisfy that need.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-hardship-distributions| title=Retirement topics - Hardship distributions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 27, 2025}}</ref> This includes hardships of your beneficiary under the plan.. Such withdrawals ''may be'' subject to early withdrawal penalties if one of the exceptions does not apply.
==In-service distribution== An '''in-service distribution''', also known as an in-service withdrawal or in-service rollover, is when a participant takes a rollover distribution from the plan while still employed at the company that is offering the plan.
IRS rules do not permit this for employees age 59½ or younger, for their elective employee pretax or Roth contributions; for participants age 59½ or older, a plan ''may'' allow it. A plan may, however, allow for in-service distributions of the employer matching contributions and of the employee's [[401(k)#After-tax_401.28k.29|after-tax 401(k)]] contributions.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://thefinancebuff.com/in-service-withdrawal-the-law-and-the-plan-rules.html| title=In-Service Withdrawal: The Law and The Plan Rules| publisher=The Finance Buff| date=February 1, 2011| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{forum link| t=50493 |title=In-service 401(k) rollover to IRA (under 40, still employed)| date=February 27, 2010}}</ref>
==Rollovers== {{Main|Retirement account at a former employer}} {{See also|IRA rollovers and transfers}}
When your employment ends, you have the following options with the 401(k) at your previous employer. The [[Retirement account at a former employer|main article]] has more detail and discusses some less common situations.
===Roll the money into your new employer's plan===
Potential advantages: *Simplicity - you have one less account to keep track of, and [[rebalancing]] is easier *Some employer plans have better investments than you can get in an IRA, or investments that could be uniquely valuable. See: [[Retirement_account_at_a_former_employer#Investments_in_employer_plans|Investments in employer plans]] *Easier access: **If you retire in the year you turn 55, you can access the money penalty-free by way of the [[Rule of 55]] **If the new employer's plan has a plan loan feature, you can use this feature with rolled in money (whereas plan loans from accounts at a former employer are not allowed) *If you work past [[Required Minimum Distribution]] (RMD) age, money in the new employer's plan is exempt from RMDs
Potential disadvantages: *The new employer's plan may have undesirable fees and/or investment choices that are not ideal
===Roll the money into an IRA===
Potential advantages: *It is easy to find [[IRA|IRAs]] with great investment choices and low fees *The account is entirely under your control, so you avoid potential complications related to your employer, such as them adding fees or changing investment options, or problems with your account such as if the employer goes out of business. *Unlike employer plans, you can withdraw money from an IRA at any time (although whether these withdrawals are subject to penalties and additional taxes is determined by [[Early withdrawal|IRS rules]]). **Although not common, if you want the ability to do [[Roth conversion|Roth conversions]] and your employer's plan does not allow In-Plan Roth Rollovers (IRRs), leaving pre-tax money in an IRA will allow this. **The [[Roth IRA]] distribution rules are generally more favorable for early distributions than for designated Roth accounts, if you want to [[Early retirement|retire early]] or need money in an emergency.
Potential disadvantages: *Any pre-tax money in a [[traditional IRA]] interferes with the [[Backdoor Roth IRA]] process. If you are a higher earner who needs to use the Backdoor Roth IRA process to contribute to a Roth IRA, this would make those contributions impossible.<ref group="note">You could still execute the Backdoor Roth IRA process, but it would act more like a taxable [[Roth conversion]], which is probably not desirable if you are adding that taxable income on top of a high earned income.</ref> This is ''not'' an issue for Roth money, as [[Roth IRA]] balances are not included in the pro-rata calculation. *Money in an IRA foregoes potential benefits from an employer plan, such as Rule of 55, plan loans (if your employer's plan has this feature), and the suspension of RMDs if you work past RMD age. Whether these features are valuable to you depends on your individual situation. *Money in an IRA generally gets less [[asset protection]] than money in an employer plan. Money in a Rollover IRA, if not commingled with other IRA money and with no direct contributions made into it, gets unlimited protection from bankruptcy at the federal level. Protection of an IRA against general creditor claims is at the state level, with some states offering limited or no protection. Money in an [[ERISA]] employer plan gets unlimited federal protection from both bankruptcy and creditor claims. *There are plenty of unscrupulous salespeople (many of whom call themselves "financial advisors") who would love to sell you poor-quality fee-laden and/or high-risk investments in an IRA, such as loaded mutual funds, annuities, permanent life insurance, private investments, and others. The investment choices in employer plans, while possibly not ideal, at least protect against predatory salespeople and scams.
===Leave the money in the former employer's plan===
Potential advantages: *If the new employer's plan is not good (or doesn't accept incoming rollovers) and you don't want to roll the money out into an IRA (for example, if you want to make Backdoor Roth IRA contributions), leaving money in the former employer's plan may be the best option *If the plan has [[Retirement_account_at_a_former_employer#Investments_in_employer_plans|desirable investments]] compared to the new employer's plan or an IRA, it could be a benefit to leave the money inside
Potential disadvantages: *You have one more account to keep track of and potentially forget about, and rebalancing is more difficult *The former employer can forcibly roll money out of the plan into an IRA if the balance is less than $7,000, or forcibly distribute it if less than $1,000 *The former employer's plan may have undesirable fees and/or investment choices that are not ideal *You cannot access the money by way of the Rule of 55 or plan loans after you separate *The account will be subject to RMDs even if you are still working for your new employer at RMD age *Although not common, investors sometimes have issues getting access to money in a former employer's plan, for example if the employer is bought out, goes out of business, etc.
===Take a distribution as cash===
This is usually advisable only if you need the money immediately and have no other sources to draw from, including taking a loan at reasonable terms. You will pay a 10% early distribution penalty if an [[Early withdrawal|exception]] does not apply. You will also owe taxes on the distribution, and Roth money withdrawn early may generate taxes that you would not pay if you waited until age 59½. In addition to these immediate taxes and penalties, you also forego the future benefits of retirement accounts, such as tax-deferred or tax-free growth, asset protection, and [[estate planning]] benefits.
==Involuntary cash out distributions==
A defined contribution plan may involuntarily cash out, also described as force out, the accounts of ex-employee participants with a balance of $7,000 or less.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p560| title=Publication 560 (2024), Retirement Plans for Small Business| publisher=IRS| accessdate=September 2, 2025}}</ref> This amount was increased from $5,000 in the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SECURE_2.0_Act SECURE 2.0 Act], effective January 1, 2024.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://keitercpa.com/blog/benefit-plan-5-reasons-leverage-secure-2-0-cashout-change/| title=Benefit Plan Insights: 5 Reasons to Leverage SECURE 2.0 Act’s Cashout Limit Change| publisher=Keiter CPAs| author=Rachel Gonner| date=April 18, 2024| accessdate=September 2, 2025}}</ref>
If the balance is between $1,000 and $7,000, then the employer must notify the participant and must provide for the automatic rollover to an [[IRA]] or annuity, unless the participant chooses otherwise. Balances of less than $1,000 may be distributed as cash/check to the participant; this will result in an [[401(k)#Early_withdrawals_and_loans|early withdrawal]] penalty and a taxable event.
A 401(k) plan is not ''required'' to make these distributions, but they ''may'', and many plans do so to reduce administrative costs of running the plans. Therefore, if you have 401(k) balances of $7,000 or less with former employers you should know the rules of your former plan(s) so you can manage your accounts successfully. If you have balances of $1,000 or less you must take extra care to monitor your accounts to ensure that they are not cashed out.
The best way to ensure a small-balance account is handled according to your investment goals is to roll the balance over to an IRA or to a new defined contribution plan (if applicable and if the plan accepts rollovers).
==Required Minimum Distributions== {{Main|Required Minimum Distribution}}
You must begin making distributions from a traditional 401(k) at least no later than the year after the year you turn 73 unless you are still employed at the company sponsoring the 401(k) plan. The minimum RMD age increases to 75 in 2033. <ref>{{cite web| url= https://natlawreview.com/article/secure-20-series-part-3-retirement-plan-required-minimum-distribution-age-to?amp | title= SECURE 2.0 Series Part 3: Retirement Plan Required Minimum Distribution Age to Increase to 75 | publisher=National Law Review}}</ref> The amount of the distribution is based on life expectancy according to the relevant factors from the [[IRA Distribution Tables | appropriate IRS tables]]. The only exception to minimum distribution is for people still working once they reach that age, and the exception only applies to the current plan they are participating in. There is a penalty for failing to make the minimum distribution. The penalty is 25% of the amount that should have been distributed, reduced to 10% if corrected within two years. Prior to 2024, RMDs were also required in Roth 401(k)s. Starting in 2024 and later years, RMDs are no longer required from designated Roth 401(k) and 403(b) accounts.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plan-and-ira-required-minimum-distributions-faqs#:~:text=Designated%20Roth%20accounts%20in%20a,required%20from%20designated%20Roth%20accounts | title= Retirement plan and IRA Required Minimum Distributions FAQs | publisher=Internal Revenue Service}}</ref>
==Beneficiaries==
If you die while holding the plan, your designated beneficiaries may rollover their inherited balance to an IRA, which will be treated as an inherited IRA.
===Successor beneficiaries=== If the designated beneficiary stays in the plan, successor beneficiaries of the designated beneficiary may not rollover an inherited balance to an IRA, per Sec 402(c)(11). A 401(k) plan ''may'', however, choose to allow successor beneficiaries to stay in the plan, and take required minimum distribution requirements using the same schedule that the original designated beneficiary was using.<ref>{{forum link|p=2214160|title=TSP Beneficiary Account and Tax Burden to Successors|author=Alan S|date=October 4, 2014}}</ref>
==Expensive or mediocre choices== Even in a bad 401(k), you should contribute up to the company match. Choose the lowest-cost funds; many bad 401(k)s have a few lower-cost funds. If you are eligible, additional contributions should usually go into a Roth or Traditional IRA. But unless your 401(k) is very bad and you expect to stay a very long time with the same employer, investing unmatched money in the 401(k) is likely to be better than taxable investing, because you can roll over your 401(k) to a low-cost IRA when you leave.
A reasonable rule-of-thumb is to consider investing in a taxable account if the product of the extra costs and the number of years you will stay in the plan exceeds one and a half times your combined federal and state tax rates on qualified dividends over your working career. That is, if you pay 1.70% expenses rather than 0.20%, and you pay 15% federal tax on qualified dividends, plus 5% state tax, you should still invest in the plan unless you are reasonably certain that you will stay with the employer for more than 20 years for a net loss of 30% (actually 26% because of compounding). If you pay no state tax, you should still invest in the plan unless you are reasonably certain you will stay more than 15 years.
The reason for the rule of thumb is that a long-term investment, even in a tax-efficient stock fund, is likely to lose more than your tax rate to taxes. You will pay tax every year on the dividends, continue to pay that tax after you leave the employer, and then pay capital-gains tax on most of the investment value when you sell the fund over the course of your retirement. (And if you retire in a 15% tax bracket and thus pay no capital gains on the fund sale, the lower tax bracket will also reduce the tax due on withdrawals from a 401(K), for a comparable tax savings.)<ref group="note">[https://thefinancebuff.com/alternatives-to-a-high-cost-401k-or-403b-plan.html Alternatives to a High Cost 401(k) Or 403(b) Plan] at [https://thefinancebuff.com TheFinanceBuff.com] contains a spreadsheet which can be used to compare alternatives for your situation (July 23, 2008). The spreadsheet approximately agrees with the rule-of-thumb estimates for the common situation in which you have 20-30 years with the employer and then average about another 10 years in retirement.</ref>
Now, before you consider forgoing your 401(k), you may want to talk to the human resources department to see if they can improve the 401(k) plan. You may want to suggest a low-cost plan like Employee Fiduciary.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.employeefiduciary.com/| title=401(k) Plans for Small Businesses| publisher=Employee Fiduciary| accessdate=January 9, 2024}}</ref> You can find a sample letter to the human resources department at {{forum link| t=7573| title=401(k) links and suggestions}}. Keep in mind that the employer likely cares more about the cost of running the 401(k) plan than the expense ratios that the employees have to live with. For this reason, it is not a good idea to stress the problem with the expense ratios too much. (See [[How to campaign for a better 401(k) plan]] for more details, as well as [https://thefinancebuff.com/alternatives-to-a-high-cost-401k-or-403b-plan.html Alternatives to a High Cost 401(k) Or 403(b) Plan] for more guidance).
==Employer administration== ===Investment policy statements=== Employers are expected to have investment policy statements for the plan, governing the process by which investment selections are chosen and monitored on an ongoing basis.
===Timing of contributions=== Contributions deferred from an employee's pay must be contributed to the 401(k) plan and allocated to your account "as of the earliest date" the deferrals can be segregated from the employer's assets. According to Department of Labor regulation 2510.3-102, the "earliest date" is the earlier of (1) the first date reasonably practicable on an ongoing basis based on the routine processing of the payroll information, transmittal of data to the plan provider and processing by the provider or (2) the 15th business day of the month following the month in which the contribution was withheld from the employee's pay. Employers are violating ERISA and subject to 15% tax on the deemed interest when failing to contribute timely.
===Plan financial reports=== Plan financial reports are filed on form 5500, 5500-C or 5500-R. Some of the information from these reports must be made available to employees, often on the company intranet.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/iam/pdf/RBA_052008_01.pdf| title=Regulatory Brief: Update on Plan Fee Disclosure| publisher=Vanguard| date=May 2008| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818142722/https://institutional.vanguard.com/iam/pdf/RBA_052008_01.pdf| archive-date=August 18, 2011}}</ref>

{{US|reason=irrelevant}} {{for|additional information|wikipedia:403(b)}} The '''403(b)''' is a tax deferred, defined contribution plan available to [[403b plans for K-12 public school district employees|employees of educational institutions such as public school districts]] and certain (Internal Revenue Code section) 501(c)(3) non-profit groups, which include colleges, universities, hospitals, charities and the clergy.[http://www.irs.gov/publications/p571/index.html IRS Publication 571 Tax-Sheltered Annuity Plans(403(b)Plans)] ==Plan basics== Contributions to a 403(b) plan are tax-deductible, and any earnings accumulate tax-free until withdrawals are made. Withdrawals are taxed at ordinary income rates, and a 10% penalty tax is assessed on withdrawals made prior to the age of 59 ½. In 2026, catch-up contributions must be made to a Roth account if the employee's 2025 salary was more than $150,000. Employees may contribute up to 100% of their salaries, subject to the following limits: {{Retirement Plan Contribution Limits}} ===Roth 403(b)=== Beginning in 2006, 403(b) plans have been allowed the option of providing a Roth 403(b). The Roth 403(b) allows individuals to contribute after-tax dollars to grow tax free and, generally, not be taxed upon withdrawal. A qualified Roth 403(b) distribution is generally a distribution that is made after a 5-taxable-year period of participation and is either: #made on or after the date you attain age 59½ #made after your death, or #attributable to your being disabled. When you roll over a distribution from a designated Roth account to a Roth IRA, the period that the rolled-over funds were in the designated Roth account '''does not count''' toward the 5-taxable-year period for determining qualified distributions from the Roth IRA. However, if you had contributed to any Roth IRA in a prior year, the 5-taxable-year period for determining qualified distributions from a Roth IRA is measured from the earlier contribution. So, if the earlier contribution was made more than 5 years ago and you are over 59 ½ a distribution of amounts attributable to a rollover contribution from a designated Roth account would be a qualified distribution from the Roth IRA.
If you take a distribution from your designated Roth account before the end of the 5-taxable-year period, it is a nonqualified distribution. You must include the earnings portion of the nonqualified distribution in gross income. However, the basis (or contributions) portion of the nonqualified distribution is not included in gross income. The basis portion of the distribution is determined by multiplying the amount of the nonqualified distribution by the ratio of designated Roth contributions to the total designated Roth account balance.
For example, if a nonqualified distribution of $5,000 is made from your designated Roth account when the account consists of $9,400 of designated Roth contributions and $600 of earnings, the distribution consists of $4,700 of designated Roth contributions (that are not includible in your gross income) and $300 of earnings (that are includible in your gross income). See [http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Retirement-Plans-FAQs-on-Designated-Roth-Accounts#distns FAQ's on Designated Roth Accounts], IRS. If the plan contains a Roth option, an employee can direct 403(b) contributions to a regular 403(b), a Roth 403(b), or some combination of the two plans; the total contribution cannot exceed the annual contribution limit.[http://www.403bwise.com/participants/getwise_faq.html 403bwise FAQ] A Roth 403(b) is no longer subject to required minimum distributions during the owner's lifetime.[http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Retirement-Plans-FAQs-regarding-Required-Minimum-Distributions Retirement Plans FAQs regarding Required Minimum Distributions], IRS A Roth 403(b) may be attractive under the following circumstances: * If you expect your tax rate in retirement will be higher than it had been during the years you contributed. * If you are young and want to use a long investment horizon to accumulate tax-free earnings under a Roth feature. * If you are a highly compensated individual who would like to have a pool of tax-free money to draw upon after retirement, and who are not eligible for Roth IRAs due to the income limitations. * If you want to leave tax-free money to heirs. ===Fifteen year rule=== Employees with 15 or more years of service with public school systems, hospitals, home health service agencies, health and welfare agencies, churches, or convention or associations of churches may be able to qualify for a Salary Reduction Catch-Up. This option is only available to those whose prior contributions have averaged less than $5,000 per year. If this qualification is met, the employee may be able to defer an extra $3,000 per annum in catch-up contributions (to a lifetime maximum of $15,000). In the ordering of contributions, the IRS deems that the 15 year service catch-up contributions precede the age 50 catch-up contributions. [http://www.403bwise.com/participants/getwise_faq.html#faq28 How much can be contributed to a 403(b)], 403(b)wise.com, FAQ For detailed rules regarding the Fifteen Year Rule consult [http://www.irs.gov/publications/p571/ch04.html#en_US_201212_publink1000239675 Publication 571] '' Tax Sheltered Annuity Plans (403(b)Plans)'', IRS {| class="wikitable" |''Example'': Andrea Miller, age 51, makes a $22,500 contribution to her 403(b) plan in 2016. The IRS allocates the contribution as follows: * Regular contribution : $18,000 * 15 year service catch-up: $3,000 * Over 50 catch-up: $1,500 Andrea Miller's remaining lifetime 15 year service catch-up total is reduced to $12,000. |} ===Distributions=== Basic rules regarding distributions from a 403(b) plan include: * A withdrawal of assets prior to age 59-1/2, will be taxable at income tax rates and will result in the IRS imposing a 10 percent penalty tax (unless certain criteria are met.) Withdrawals are taxable unless you meet one of the following exclusions: *Attain age 59-1/2 *Separate from service in or after the year in which you reach age 55 *Part of a series of substantially equal periodic payments for your life or the joint lives of you and your designated beneficiary *Hardship *Disability *Death *Made due to an IRS levy upon your participant account *Paid to an alternative payee under a qualified domestic relations order *Is a qualified reservist distribution as defined under the Pension Protection Act of 2006 *Is a payment of qualified medical expenses greater than 7.2% of your adjusted gross income. Source: [http://www.403bwise.com/participants/getwise_faq.html 403bwise FAQ] * Penalty-free withdrawals are allowed upon retirement (assumed to be in or after the year in which you reach age 55). * Generally, required minimum distributions, must begin from a 403(b) no later than April 1 of the year following the year in which an individual turns age 73. If you are still working, you can delay withdrawal from your 403(b) until April 1 following the year in which you retire. * 403(b) account balances that existed on December 31, 1986 are not subject to the age 70-1/2 distribution requirement. However, any earnings on that balance are. Distribution from the 12/31/86 balance needs to start at age 75. (This situation is complex, and consulting a professional tax advisor is recommended.) If you own more than one 403(b), required minimum distributions are calculated in a manner similar to an IRA. You must calculate the RMD separately for each 403(b) contract that you own, but can take the total amount from one or more of the 403(b) contracts.This is similar to an IRA, where an IRA owner must calculate the RMD separately for each IRA that they own, but can withdraw the total amount from one or more of the IRAs. However, RMDs required from other types of retirement plans, such as 401(k) and 457(b) plans have to be taken separately from each of those plan accounts. Reference: [http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Retirement-Plans-FAQs-regarding-Required-Minimum-Distributions#5 Retirement Plans FAQs regarding Required Minimum Distributions], from the IRS. ===Transfers=== {{401k rollover infobox}} A number of tax-free transfers and rollovers of 403(b) plans are permissible under the tax laws. * '''Contract exchanges'''. If you transfer all or part of your interest from a 403(b) contract to another 403(b) contract (held in the same plan), the transfer is tax free, and is referred to as a contract exchange. This was previously known as a 90-24 transfer. A contract exchange is similar to a 90-24 transfer with one major difference. Previously, you were able to accomplish the transfer without your employer’s involvement. After September 24, 2007, all such transfers are accomplished through a contract exchange requiring your employer’s involvement. In addition, the plan must provide for the exchange and the transferred interest must be subject to the same or stricter distribution restrictions. Finally, your accumulated benefit after the exchange must be equal to what it was before the exchange.[http://www.irs.gov/publications/p571/ch08.html#en_US_201212_publink1000239748 IRS Pub 571] * If you leave your employer assets can be transferred to your new employer's defined contribution plan, if permitted by that plan. * After leaving your employer, assets may be moved to a Rollover Individual Retirement Account (IRA). ==Advantages== The advantages a 403(b) plan offers include the following. [http://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/10/top-9-benefits-403b-plans.asp Top 9 Benefits Of A 403(b) plan], Eric Fontinelle, (April 6, 2010), investipedia * High contribution limits allow an individual to tax defer more investment dollars than can be contributed to individual retirement plans. * Contributions to a regular 403(b) are tax deductible. Tax deductible contributions are especially advantageous if the tax rate is lower when retirement income withdrawals are made. If a Roth option is available, contributions made at low tax rates are advantageous if the tax rate is higher when retirement withdrawals are made. * Contributions made to a 403(b) qualify for the Retirement Savings Contributions Credit ([[Saver's credit|Saver's Credit]]) if you meet the filing and income requirements. [http://www.irs.gov/publications/p571/ch10.html Retirement Savings Contributions Credit (Saver's Credit)], Publication 571, IRS * Employer's can make [[Employer matching contributions|matching contributions]] to employee contributions. * Some plans may have loan provisions. IRS stipulations regarding 403(b)loans limits loans to the lesser of: *$50,000 *One half of account value The individual vendor may put additional restrictions on loan provisions. See [http://403bwise.com/participants/getwise_403b_access.html assessing 403(b)savings], 403(b)wise.com * If a 403(b) plan offers very low-cost investment options (such as those offered by [[TIAA-CREF]] in the university retirement plan market, or by a low cost mutual fund company) investors can reap most of the returns investment markets provide. Unfortunately, the 403(b) marketplace, especially in the K-12 school environment, is primarily populated by high cost, commissioned annuity products. [http://www.403bwise.com/participants/getwise_reading.html must reads], 403(b)wise.com. ''[http://www.403bwise.com/pdf/who_is_watching_door_full.pdf Whose Watching The Door? How Controlling Provider Access Can Improve K-12 Teacher Retirement Outcomes]'', Research Dialogue, Issue No,. 98, TIAA-CREF Institute * 403(b) plans allow employees who have fifteen years of service to an employer to make up to $15,000 of catch up contributions to the plan. * Participants who are eligible for both a 403(b) and a [[457(b)|457(b)]] through their employer can contribute the maximum of both plans, which at $23,000 each is a combined $46,000. See [http://www.457bwise.com/faqs/index.html#contributeboth 457(b)wise] FAQ for more information on 457(b) plans ==Criticisms== [[File:Fees-impact-return.gif|thumb|right|450px|Value after 35 years, assuming $250 contributed monthly with an 8 percent average annual return.]] Since the 403(b) is heavily tied to the insurance industry, '''History of the 403(b) Plan''' *403(b) programs were originally created in 1958 by Congress for employees of tax-exempt corporations. *In 1961, public education institutions, including public school districts, became eligible to offer 403(b) plans. *In 1973, Congress passed a law allowing employees to make tax-free exchanges of the full account value from one 403(b) plan to another, and partial transfers have been allowed since 1992. *In 1974, Congress passed the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), which included a provision allowing 403(b) plans to increase the number of their investment options and offer mutual funds in addition to annuities. *In 1978, a law was passed allowing employees to roll 403(b) assets into a traditional IRA. *Starting in 1982, with the passage of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act, 403(b) participants were allowed to take loans from their plans. Additionally, religious organizations were permitted to set up Retirement Income Accounts, a specialized form of 403(b) plan. *In 1986, another tax law imposed restrictions on withdrawals before age 59½ and made them subject to a 10 percent early withdrawal penalty. Additionally, required minimum distributions (after age 70½) were established along with new limits on elective deferrals. The limit established then, $9,500 per person per year, remained in effect until 1998. *A 1992 IRS ruling allowed employees to make tax-free full or partial account transfers from annuities to 403(b)(7) mutual fund accounts. *The 2001 tax bill, which took effect in 2002, allowed 403(b) participants to roll their money into a 401(k) or governmental 457 plan when changing jobs, in addition to an IRA or other 403(b). Similarly, employees with savings in 401(k) or governmental 457 plans may roll their contributions into a 403(b) plan, if offered by their new employer. The tax bill also simplified the formula used to calculate an employee's annual contribution limit. * On July 23, 2007, the IRS finalized new regulations (set to go into full effect January 1, 2009) for public 403(b) retirement plans. The main highlights include: ** Requirement that a 403(b) program be maintained pursuant to a written plan which satisfies section 403(b) in both form and operation and contains all the terms and conditions for eligibility, limitations, and benefits under the plan. ** End to traditional 90-24 outside-of-plan transfers. ** Requirement to provide annual notification of eligibility ** Clarification of universal availability ** New information sharing requirements between employers and vendors. These products often come with an extra layer of fees and restrictions such as surrender charges; According to the SEC [http://www.sec.gov/investor/pubs/teacheroptions.htm Evaluating Your Retirement Options]:{{blockquote| For example, if you withdraw money from a variable annuity within a certain period after a purchase payment (typically within six to eight years, but sometimes as long as ten years), the insurance company usually will assess a "surrender" charge. Mutual funds are a possible option (known as 403(b)(7) custodial accounts) only if they are an available option within the plan. If mutual funds are not available in the 403(b) the participant should consider lobbying the employer to offer some lower fee mutual funds. <onlyinclude>Created in 1978, a '''457(b)''' plan is a non-qualified tax-deferred compensation plan similar to qualified plans such as the [[401(k)]] and [[403(b)]]. If you work for a state or local government or for a tax-exempt organization, you may be able to participate in a section 457 deferred compensation plan.<ref>[http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/457 26 USC § 457 - Deferred compensation plans of State and local governments and tax-exempt organizations], Legal Information Institute, Cornell Law School </ref> The 457 plan may be available as an additional voluntary retirement savings vehicle for state or local government or tax-exempt organization employers also offering a public employees pension system. Or they can be offered as a supplemental retirement option for those state or local government or tax-exempt organization employers offering a 401(k) or 403(b) plan.<ref>[http://www.457bwise.com/faqs/index.html 403(b)wise. 457 FAQ] </ref></onlyinclude><!--- used for retirement plan overview -->
Although 457 plans rarely provide an employer matching contribution, there is no federal 10 percent premature distribution penalty imposed on withdrawals from a 457(b) plan when separating from service.<ref>[https://403bwise.com/k12/content/18 403(b)wise. 457b]</ref>
As always, costs matter, so before investing evaluate the fees and expenses of the investment options available in the 457 plan you are considering. Each plan chooses which investment alternatives to offer eligible employees, so fund choices and associated fees and expenses can vary.
==Types of 457 plans== <onlyinclude><!--- used for retirement plan overview --> There are two basic types of 457 plans: :*''' Government Plans''': Local and state governments are eligible to establish a 457(b) plan for their employees. This type of 457(b) covers employees of a state (including the District of Columbia), a political subdivision of a state, any agency or instrumentality of a state, or political subdivision of a state. These types of employees can include: local and state government workers, fire fighters, police personnel, and public school employees.
::Section 1448 of the Small Business Jobs Protection Act of 1996 (SBJPA) added 457(g) of the Code, which requires that 457(b) plans maintained by state or local government employers hold all plan assets and income in trust, or in custodial accounts or annuity contracts (described in 401(f) of the Code), for the exclusive benefit of their participants and beneficiaries.
::Contributions to the 457(b) plan qualify for the [[Saver's credit|saver's credit]].<ref>[http://www.irs.gov/publications/p571/ch10.html Pub 571 savers credit], IRS </ref> :* '''Non-Government Plans''': Tax-exempt organizations that are non-governmental (hospitals, charitable organizations, unions, among others) must generally limit participation to a select group of management or highly compensated employees. This is due to the rules under Title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
::ERISA generally requires that a private retirement plan providing benefits to employees be funded by a trust or annuity contract. The rules, however, require that private 457(b) plans be unfunded in order to obtain tax benefits. Therefore, a plan will violate ERISA unless an exception applies. This provision means that the 457 plan assets are the property of the sponsoring employer and are subject to the employer's general creditors, until paid out to plan participants.<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/non-governmental-457b-deferred-compensation-plans. IRS Non_ Governmental 457b Deferred Compensation Plans]</ref></onlyinclude><!--- used for retirement plan overview -->
Each 457 plan is required to have a written plan document. It is essential to refer to this document for the details on how your 457 plan operates, including the investment options offered by the plan, fees and expenses, and specific withdrawal options.</onlyinclude>
===Roth 457(b)=== If an employer offers a Roth 457(b) provision, an employee can designate all or a portion of their 457(b) as an after-tax Roth contribution. These contributions are made with after tax earnings. Unlike the advantage a pre-tax 457(b) has over pre-tax 401(k) and 403(b) plans, withdrawals from a Roth 457(b) are subject to the same age 59.5 restrictions as other Roth plans. Worse yet for those taking pre-59.5 withdrawals, Roth 457(b) distributions are taken on a pro-rata basis between contributions and gains, unlike the "contributions first" treatment given to Roth IRA distributions.<ref>[https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=222789 Roth 457 vs. Roth IRA - Bogleheads.org]</ref>
Employees have the option of making pre-tax 457(b) contributions, Roth 457(b) contributions, or a combination of the two. Total contributions cannot exceed the year's contribution limit.<ref>[https://403bwise.com/k12/content/18 457(b)], 403(b)wise.com. </ref>
==Contributions== The contribution limits are the same as for other employer plans. However, participants may invest the maximum allowable contribution in both a 457 plan and a [[401(k)]] or [[403(b) | 403(b)]] plan of both are available. The combined maximum contribution for 2026 is thus $49,000. The [[#Catch up provision |"final three year"]] and Age 50+ catch-up cannot be used in the same tax year.<ref>[https://dcprovider.com/PDF/tn/Tenn_Plan_Comparison_FINAL_03182013.pdf Comparison of the Governmental 457(b) and 401(k) Plans]</ref> Also, the age 50+ and 60-63 higher limits are only applicable to governmental 457 plans, not to non-governmental plans.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Non-governmental 457(b) deferred compensation plans|url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/non-governmental-457b-deferred-compensation-plans|access-date=June 25, 2025|website=Internal Revenue Service}}</ref> The table below reflects 457 plan contribution limits, again noting that 50+ and 60-63 catchup contributions aren’t applicable to non-governmental 457 plans.<ref>{{Cite web|title=What is a 457(b) plan and how does it work?|url=https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/smart-money/what-is-a-457b|access-date=June 25, 2025|website=Fidelity Investments}}</ref> Catch-up contributions for 2026 must be made to a Roth account if the employee's 2025 salary was over $150,000.
{{Retirement Plan Contribution Limits}} ===Catch up provision=== The 457(b) plan often contains a special "catch-up" provision called the "final three year" provision for those approaching retirement (assuming they haven't contributed the maximum amount in prior years). Employers are not required to offer this provision. For those that do, the "catch-up" provision kicks in during the three years prior to "normal" retirement age (as defined in the plan). This provision, now permits up to 200% of the elective deferral limit, or $47,000 in 2025, $49,000 in 2026.
{{Notice|''Example'': Victor will reach "normal" retirement age in 2021; under his plan he can take advantage of the "final three year" provision in years 2018, 2019, and 2020. If Victor takes advantage of this provision he cannot also take advantage of the "Age 50 catch-up" provision. Note: to determine the underutilized amounts in prior years all of the prior coordination rules apply.<ref>[http://www.457bwise.com/faqs/index.html 457bwise. 457 FAQ]</ref>}}
==Investment options== 457(b) plans can be funded with: :*Group [[Fixed annuity|fixed]] and [[Variable annuity|variable annuities]] :*Retail [[Mutual fund|mutual funds]] :*Bank instruments :*A combination of all three
==Withdrawals== Government 457(b) plans are subject to income tax upon withdrawal but are not subject to the 10% early withdrawal penalty. Funds can be withdrawn at retirement, upon severance from the employer, upon death, upon disability, and under stringent hardship withdrawal rules. Funds must be withdrawn at age 73 (unless you are still working) and are subject to the [[IRA distribution tables|required minimum distributions]] rules.<ref>[http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Retirement-Plans-FAQs-regarding-Required-Minimum-Distributions Retirement Plans FAQs regarding Required Minimum Distributions], IRS </ref> Different rules apply if you work for a tax-exempt organization (you must see the employer plan document for the details.)<ref>[http://www.457bwise.com/faqs/index.html 403(b)wise. 457 FAQ]</ref>
===Hardship withdrawals=== The IRS has strict guidelines for allowable hardship withdrawals:
Under a 457(b) plan, a hardship distribution can only occur when the participant is faced with an unforeseeable emergency. (Code § 457(d)(1)(iii))
An unforeseeable emergency is a severe financial hardship resulting from an illness or accident, loss of property due to casualty, or other similar extraordinary and unforeseeable circumstances arising as a result of events beyond the control of the participant or beneficiary. Examples of events that may be considered unforeseeable emergencies include imminent foreclosure on, or eviction from, the employee's home, medical expenses, and funeral expenses. Generally, the purchase of a home and the payment of college tuition are not unforeseeable emergencies. (Reg. § 1.457-6(c)(2)(i))
Whether a participant or beneficiary is faced with an unforeseeable emergency depends on the facts and circumstances. However, a distribution is not on account of an unforeseeable emergency to the extent that the emergency can be relieved through reimbursement or compensation from insurance, liquidation of the participant's assets, or cessation of deferrals under the plan. (Reg. § 1.457-6(c)(2)(ii))
A distribution on account of an unforeseeable emergency must not exceed the amount reasonably necessary to satisfy the emergency need. (Reg. § 1.457-6(c)(2)(iii))<ref>[http://www.irs.gov/retirement/article/0,,id=162416,00.html IRS Retirement Plans FAQs regarding Hardship Distributions]</ref>
==Rollovers== {{401k rollover infobox}} An employer is not required to accept rollover contributions, so it is necessary to check a 457(b) plan's written document for its rules on plan rollovers.
Rollover provisions are more liberal for a government 457(b) plan than for non-government 457 plans. A government 457(b) plan can be rolled over to another employer's 457 plan, a 401(k) plan, a 403(b) plan or a rollover [[Traditional IRA|traditional IRA.]] However, assets transferred out of the 457 into a non 457 plan will lose the exemption to the early withdrawal penalty that 457 plans enjoy. Likewise, if you roll non 457 plan assets into an employer provided 457 plan, these assets do not gain exemption from the early withdrawal penalty.
Non-government 457 plans can only be rolled over to another non government 457 plan.<ref>[http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p4484.pdf IRS:Choose a Retirement Plan]</ref>
